title: Mode field diameter
text:
In <a href="fiber%20optics">fiber optics</a>, the mode field diameter (MFD) is a measure of the width of an <a href="irradiance">irradiance</a> distribution, i.e., the optical <a href="Power%20%28physics%29">power</a> per unit area, across the end face of a <a href="Single-mode%20optical%20fiber">single-mode fiber</a>. It is analogous to the formula_1 measure of the <a href="beam%20diameter">beam diameter</a> for a beam propagating in free space.
The mode field diameter is defined as twice the mode field radius, and the mode field radius is equal to the distance from the center at which the <a href="electric%20field">electric</a> and <a href="magnetic%20field">magnetic field</a> strengths are reduced to formula_2 of their maximum values. Since the intensity (given by the <a href="Poynting%20vector">Poynting vector</a>) is proportional to the square of the field amplitude, the intensity drops by formula_3 or -8.69 dB at this distance from the center. For a <a href="Gaussian%20beam">Gaussian-shaped mode</a>, the mode field diameter is twice the beam waist formula_4.
The MFD is typically slightly larger than the <a href="Core%20%28optical%20fiber%29">core</a> of an optical fiber extending slightly into the <a href="Cladding%20%28fiber%20optics%29">cladding</a>.
